case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 909 to 923 of 1963 are appeals from the judgment and orders dated July 26, and August 1, 1962, of the Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 909 to 923 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment and orders dated July 26, and August 1, 1962, of the Calcutta High Court in Appeals from Original Orders Nos. 288 and 274-276, 278, 280, 279, 281, 273, 272, 271, 270, 269, 282 and 292 of 1961.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation of India terminated the services of its employees who are the respondents in these 15 appeals.

anchor.surface_text: This is a group of 15 appeals which raise a common question about the validity of the orders passed by the appellant Life Insurance Corporation of India terminating the services of its employees who are the respondents in these appeals.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee was in the insurance line since June, 1941 and had been confirmed in his service by the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. in March, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: One of the respondents is Sunil Kumar Mukherjee. He was in the insurance line since June, 1941 and had been confirmed in his service by the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. in March, 1950.

facts.text: Sunil Kumar Mukherjee had been working as Inspector since about 1953, and since March 18, 1955, as Inspector at Barrackpore.

anchor.surface_text: Since about 1953, he had been working as Inspector of the said Company, and since March 18, 1955, he was holding the appointment as Inspector at Barrackpore.

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation took over the controlled business of the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. and terminated services of Mukherjee on October 16, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant which took over the controlled business of the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd., terminated the services of Mukherjee by an order passed on the 16th October, 1958.

facts.text: Mukherjee moved Calcutta High Court under Art. 226 for writ of certiorari quashing the discharge order.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent then- moved the Calcutta High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution and prayed for a writ of certiorari or other appropriate writ or order quashing the said impugned order of discharge passed against him.

facts.text: Sinha J. allowed the writ petition and issued certiorari and mandamus.

anchor.surface_text: Sinha J. who heard the writ petition allowed the petition and directed that a writ in the nature of certiorari quashing and or setting aside the impugned order be issued. A further writ in the nature of mandamus was also issued

facts.text: Division Bench of Calcutta High Court (Bose C.J. and Debabrata Mookerjee J.) confirmed Sinha J.'s order in Letters Patent appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of Sinha J. the appellants preferred an appeal under the Letters Patent before a Division Bench of the said High Court. Bose C.J. and Debabrata Mokerjee J. who heard the Letters Patent appeal substantially agreed

facts.text: Appointment of Mukherjee as whole-time Inspector by Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. on 18th or 19th March, 1955 with terms in Annexure A.

anchor.surface_text: When Mr.Mukherjee was appointed a whole-time Inspector by the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd. on the 18th or 19th March, 1955, the terms and conditions of his employment were communicated to him by a document which contained 14 clauses

facts.text: Clause 13 of appointment document: termination without notice for fraud etc., 30 days notice otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 13 of this document provided that the appointment was subject to termination without notice in case he was found guilty of fraud, misappropriation, breach of discipline, insubordination, acting detrimental to the interests of the company,

facts.text: Order dated February 14, 1958 appointed Mukherjee as Field Officer attached to Barrackpore Branch.

anchor.surface_text: When the Life Insurance Corpn. took over the business of the Metropolitan Insurance Co. Ltd., an order was issued in favour of Mr. Mukherjee on the 14th February, 1958. By this order it was stated that in terms of Government Order No.

facts.text: Termination order of October 16, 1958 based on section 5 of Categorisation circular of December 2, 1957 and Special Committee recommendation.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th October, 1958, the impugned order terminating Mr. Mukherjees services was passed. This order said that in terms of section 5 of the Categorisation circular of the 2nd December, 1957, Mr. Mukherjees case was examined

facts.text: Life Insurance (Emergency Provisions) Ordinance No. 1 of 1956 promulgated on January 19, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The history of the nationalisation of the Life Insurance business in this country is well-known. On the 19th January, 1956, the Life Insurance  Emergency Provisions  Ordinance  No. 1 of 1956  was promulgated by the President

facts.text: Life Insurance Corporation Act No. 31 of 1956 published on July 1, 1956, appointed day September 1, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This Act was followed by Act 31 of 1956  hereinafter called the Act  which was published on the 1st of July, 1956. The appointed date under s.3 of this Act was the 1st of September,1956.

facts.text: Section 7 of Act: on appointed day, controlled business of insurers transferred to Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Act provides that on the appointed day there shall be transferred to and vested in the Corporation all the assets and liabilities appertaining to the controlled business of all insurers.

facts.text: Section 11(1): whole-time employees of insurers become employees of Corporation on appointed day with same terms.

anchor.surface_text: Every whole-time employee of an insurer whose controlled business has been transferred to and vested in the Corporation and who was employed by the insurer wholly or mainly in connection with his controlled business immediately before

facts.text: Central Government order dated December 30, 1957 (blue order) altering terms for Field Officers under section 11(2).

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th December, 1957, an order was issued by the Central Government in exercise of the powers conferred on it by s. 11 2  of the Act. This order was issued on blue paper and has been described by the High Court

facts.text: Clause 10 of the Field Officers Order, 1957 provides for termination procedures: with enquiry or with Chairman's approval and 3 months notice.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 10 is relevant for our purpose and must be set out in full Penalties and termination of service In case of unsatisfactory performance of duties by a Development Officer or if a Development Officer shows negligence

facts.text: Regulations framed in 1958 under s.49 incorporating Categorisation circular of December 2, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: As envisaged by clause 11 of the Order, Regulations were framed in 1958 by the Life Insurance Corporation under s. 49 of the Act read with clause 11 of the Order. These Regulations contain five Clauses

facts.text: Paragraph 4(h) of December 2, 1957 circular: cases with performance less than 50% of quota referred to Committee for review, possible termination.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 4, clause  h  reads thus- If the actual performance is less than 50of the revised quota, the cases of such Field Officers will be referred to a Committee to be specially appointed in each Zone.

facts.text: No enquiry held and no opportunity given under clause 10(a), nor prior approval under 10(b) for terminations.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that before terminating the services of the respective respondents in the group of appeals before us, no enquiry has been held and no opportunity has been given to the said officers

facts.text: Supreme Court holds termination orders invalid for not complying with clause 10 of the Order.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already seen, it is common ground that the impugned orders terminating the services of the respective respondents have not been passed in accordance either with clause 10 a  or 10 b , and so, they must be held

facts.text: Appeals dismissed, High Court orders confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the orders passed by the High Court are confirmed, and the appeals are dismissed with costs.

issues.text: whether the High Court was in error in holding that the orders of discharge passed respectively against the respondents in these appeals were invalid

anchor.surface_text: a common question which has been raised by the learned Solicitor-General on behalf of the appellants is that the High Court was in error in holding that the orders of discharge passed respectively against the respondents in these appeals were invalid.

issues.text: what is the effect of this order of appointment

anchor.surface_text: One of the points which we have to consider in the present appeal is what is the effect of this order of appointment?

issues.text: whether the termination of their services can be brought about only under clause 10 a or 10 b of the Order, and since it has not been so brought about, the impugned orders are invalid or whether the power to terminate services conferred by paragraph 4 h of the circular is independent of clause 10 of the Order

anchor.surface_text: The respondents contention is that the termination of their services can be brought about only under clause 10 a or 10 b of the Order, and since it has not been so brought about, the impugned orders are invalid. On the other hand, the learned Solicitor-General contends that the power to terminate services conferred by paragraph 4 h of the circular is independent of clause 10 of the Order,

issues.text: the true legal position about the character of the relevant statutory provisions

anchor.surface_text: In considering the validity of these rival contentions, it is necessary to bear in mind the true legal position about the character of the relevant statutory provisions.

issues.answer: s.11(2) paramount; Order as rules under s.48; Regulations subordinate

issues.text: whether paragraph 4 h and clause 10 can be reasonably reconciled

anchor.surface_text: paragraph 4 h and clause 10 can be reasonably reconciled

issues.text: whether the order terminating his services is valid either under para 4 h of the circular or under s. 11(2) of the Act
whether relief under Art. 311(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: in the present proceedings the respondents had claimed relief under Art. 311 2 of the Constitution and had in their writ petitions challenged the validity of the Order and the Regulations.

arguments.claim: Provisions contained in s.11(2) of the Act are paramount and override contrary provisions in Order or Regulations

anchor.surface_text: In considering the validity of these rival contentions, it is necessary to bear in mind the true legal position about the character of the relevant statutory provisions. It is plain that the provisions contained in s. 11 2 of the Act are paramount and would override any contrary provisions contained in. the Order or the Regulations.

arguments.claim: Provisions of the Order prevail over Regulations as Order partakes character of rules under s.48

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions of s. 11 2 , the provisions of the Order will prevail, because the Order has been issued by the Central Government by virtue of the powers conferred on it by s. 11 2  itself The provisions of the Order in law partake of the character of the rules framed under s. 48 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Paragraph 4(h) and clause 10 can be reasonably reconciled; termination under 4(h) must comply with clause 10

anchor.surface_text: paragraph 4 h and clause 10 can be reasonably reconciled. What we have said about para 4 h is equally true about paragraph 5 of the circular.

arguments.claim: Impugned orders terminating services invalid as not in accordance with clause 10(a) or 10(b)

anchor.surface_text: As we have already seen, it is common ground that the impugned orders terminating the services of the respective respondents have not been passed in accordance either with clause 10 a  or 10 b , and so, they must be held

arguments.claim: Respondents entitled to relief on alternative basis of non-compliance with clause 10 despite claiming under Art.311(2)

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in the present proceedings the respondents had claimed relief under Art. 311 2 of the Constitution and had in their writ petitions challenged the validity of the Order and the Regulations. That, however, does not dis- entitle the respondents from claiming the same relief on the alternative basis

arguments.claim: The order terminating Haridas Roy's services is valid either under para 4(h) of the circular or under s.11(2) of the Act
arguments.court_reasoning: Cannot demote or terminate for refusing lower post; must fix salary under clause 5 and apply s.11(2) if refused

arguments.claim: What is the effect of the order of appointment dated February 14, 1958

anchor.surface_text: One of the points which we have to consider in the present appeal is what is the effect of this order of appointment?

court_response_anchor.surface_text: 1956, the Life Insurance  Emergency Provisions  Ordinance  No. 1 of 1956  was promulgated by the President for the purpose of tak

arguments.court_reasoning: Appointed as Field Officer under Government Order, subject to Field Officers Order

holdings.text: the impugned orders terminating the services of the respective respondents have not been passed in accordance either with clause 10 a or 10 b , and so, they must be held to be invalid
holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground that no enquiry/opportunity under 10(a) or prior Chairman approval under 10(b); para 4(h) requires compliance with clause 10

holdings.text: paragraph 4 h and clause 10 can be reasonably reconciled. ... the termination of the services of the said officers must be effected in the manner prescribed by clause 10 of the Order
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: para 4(h) makes services liable to termination but procedure governed by superior clause 10 of Order

holdings.text: the provisions contained in s. 11 2 of the Act are paramount and would override any contrary provisions contained in. the Order or the Regulations
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory hierarchy: s.11(2) overrides notwithstanding clause

holdings.text: the provisions of the Order will prevail, because the Order has been issued by the Central Government by virtue of the powers conferred on it by s. 11 2  itself The provisions of the Order in law partake of the character of the rules framed under s. 48 of the Act
holdings.reasoning_summary: Order under s.11(2) equivalent to rules under s.48, superior to regulations

holdings.text: Regulations made by the Corporation under s. 49 are found to be inconsistent either with s. 11  2  or with the Order made by the Central Government -under s. 11 2 , they would be invalid
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.49 regulations subordinate, must conform to Act and rules (Order)

holdings.text: That, however, does not dis- entitle the respondents from claiming the same relief on the alternative basis that though the Order and the Regulations may be valid, the impugned orders whereby their services have been terminated are invalid

anchor.surface_text: It is true that in the present proceedings the respondents had claimed relief under Art. 311  2  of the Constitution and had in their writ petitions challenged the validity of the Order and the Regulations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relief grantable on alternative ground despite primary claim under Art.311(2)

holdings.text: the order terminating his services because he refused to take an assignment as an Assistant can be justified. It would have been open to the Corporation to fix Roys salary at the minimum in the grade prescribed by clause 5 of the Order
holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulations fix pay within grade, not demote; termination for refusal of lower post invalid

holdings.text: the orders passed by the High Court are confirmed, and the appeals are dismissed with costs
holdings.reasoning_summary: All above holdings lead to dismissal
